comment: Adams lost in round six and was the odd man out in round 7, so he really needs to win. But, he beat Ponomariov in round 2, so is it really to be expected that he could beat him again?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O
comment: Considering his need to win this is a good choice.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3
comment: Taking on the Marshall Gambit head-on is a curious choice,but if he should win he'd again be in a tie for first with Kasparov (who is odd man out this round) . Apparently this is a crucial game for both players. And, Ponomariov would probably like to get revenge for his earlier loss to Adams.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5
comment: One doesn't often see the Marshall Gambit at the highest GM levels. It's not refuted or considered to be overwhelming, but most players simply don't like to walk into a variation with which they're not fully prepared and their opponent may know the theory 30 moves deep.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4
comment: Rather than develop pieces White immediately threatens Re4-h4 to eject Qh3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2
comment: This indicates an intention to give back some material (as Re4 is pretty well stuck in the middle of the board) and not to spend time chasing Qh3 back. He's only committed to this after Black weakened his king's position with 15...g5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6
comment: Black has no reason to give his Bc8 for Re4 when the knight can do the job.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3
comment: White's Nd2 is a key to this formation. If it moves Black breaks through at e4. If White can cause Black to capture at e4 he'll recapture Nd2xe4 and from e4 the knight threatens Bd6 or Ne4-f6+ and in some cases Ne4-f2.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5
comment: With White's Re4 and Qe2 clogging the e-file Black can't find a way to activate his rooks, so he tries to create another target with c5xd4, or does he only intend ...c5-c4 to block out Bb3? It's hard to know what's on his mind at this point.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4
comment: Though he kicks Bb3 back he's also extended the pawn further than it can easily be supported. This fact gives White an opportunity to counter on the queen-side, where one should recall/recognize White has more pawns.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2
comment: a way of developing which I'd bet is extremely rare for this opening variation

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4
comment: The position is changing, away from the earlier direct assault on Kg1, and Re4 might be lost for no perceptible gain. It's a wide open tactical slugfest!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6
comment: Black still wants ...Rc8-c2.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5
comment: After this White has things secured and he might consider d4-d5 to open up Bb2 (and possibly Qf2-d4) or Ra1-c1.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8
comment: Black begins a plan of invasion: ...Bg6-d3, ...Re8-e2. This keeps Qf2 tied down, but it doesn't really prevent d4-d5-d6 to create general piece activity for White.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5
comment: threatening Bxf6

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7
comment: It's hard to find a better move, but he shouldn't play this unless he really intends to capture Rc5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3
comment: White offers Rc5 again, knowing the two advanced connected passed pawns (a Pc5 and Pd5) would be powerful and very unappealing to Black. Black's offense is quickly receding and Kg1 looks completely safe.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4
comment: White does a good job of restraining Nd7 with some offense. Pf4 prevents ...Nd7-e5, but it can also advance to block Bg6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4 h4 31. f5 hxg3 32. hxg3 Bh5 33. d6
comment: crucial to prevent ...Nd7-e5-f3+

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4 h4 31. f5 hxg3 32. hxg3 Bh5 33. d6 Re4 34. Rac1
comment: White's plan now seems to be to trade-off or get rid of Rd8 and Nd7, so Pd6 can advance. Black has generated enough of a threat to Kg1 so that he'd be risking a lot to move away Qf2. So, Kg8 remains safe for now.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4 h4 31. f5 hxg3 32. hxg3 Bh5 33. d6 Re4 34. Rac1 Nxc5 35. bxc5 Kh7 36. Bf6 Rg8 37. d7 Rh4
comment: threat: ...Qh3-h1#. Rg8 helps to make it impossible for White to capture Rh4. White intends to spend as few tempi as possible defending, so he can push through Pd7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4 h4 31. f5 hxg3 32. hxg3 Bh5 33. d6 Re4 34. Rac1 Nxc5 35. bxc5 Kh7 36. Bf6 Rg8 37. d7 Rh4 38. Qg2 Bf3 39. Qxh3 Rxh3
comment: Black threatens ...Rh3-h1+ and ...Rxc1 to get behind Pc5. He'd sacrifice Rg8 for one pawn, but he has to stop the other from advancing.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. c3 d5 9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 12. d4 Bd6 13. Re1 Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Re4 g5 16. Qe2 Nf6 17. Nd2 Bf5 18. f3 c5 19. Qf2 c4 20. Bc2 h6 21. b3 cxb3 22. axb3 Rfc8 23. Bb2 Bb4 24. Re5 Bxc2 25. cxb4 Bg6 26. Rc5 Re8 27. Nf1 Rad8 28. d5 Nd7 29. Ne3 h5 30. f4 h4 31. f5 hxg3 32. hxg3 Bh5 33. d6 Re4 34. Rac1 Nxc5 35. bxc5 Kh7 36. Bf6 Rg8 37. d7 Rh4 38. Qg2 Bf3 39. Qxh3 Rxh3 40. Kf2 g4 41. Nf1 Rh5 42. d8=Q Rxd8 43. Bxd8 Rxf5 44. Ne3 Rh5 45. Bh4
comment: This neat retreating move blocks the rook completely, so Pc5 will advance and promote, probably forcing Black to give another of his pieces for it. So, Ponomariov moves into a tie with Kasparov for the lead and Adams, with three defeats in his nine games falls far behind.
